Award.AwardTitle: Using Nonsymbolic Ratios to Promote Fraction Knowledge: A Neurocognitive Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, to be conducted by researchers at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, will study knowledge of fractions in college students and eighth-graders. The project will use behavioral and brain imaging measures. The main hypothesis is that some kinds of visual perception ability (such as sensitivity to the ratio formed by the lengths of two lines) are related to fraction understanding. The project will develop a training method aimed at improving knowledge about fractions. This project will advance the work of the REAL (Research on Education and Learning) program in studying the cognitive and neural basis of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) learning.

The project will use fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) to study brain activity, focusing on brain regions including the PFC (prefrontal cortex) and IPS (intraparietal sulcus). In particular, the research will use an adaptation method, looking at activation recovery when a novel ratio is presented in a series of ratios. The project addresses a cognitive primitives account of fraction magnitude processing, which posits that perceptual sensitivity to nonsymbolic ratio magnitudes plays a major role in supporting the developing understanding of symbolic fraction magnitudes. This account implies that neurocognitive architectures tuned to the processing of non-symbolic ratio--such as the relative lengths of two lines or the relative areas of two figures--are present even before learners receive fractions instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematical skill is important for success in many areas of life, and understanding fractions is foundational for building mathematical skills. Despite the importance of fraction skills, children and adults often struggle to understand fractions. Many researchers have proposed that fractions are difficult because they are incompatible with basic human brain structures, arguing that brains have evolved to perceive whole numbers in nature, such as the number of people in a room or fingers someone is holding up. Our research tested the competing hypothesis that people can perceive non-symbolic fractions?like line segments in a 1:2 ratio? and that this can support reasoning about fractions concepts. This cognitive primitives hypothesis argues that children have innate abilities that support fraction concepts and that formal instruction can help learners build links between these innate nonsymbolic fraction intuitions and formal fractions that are learned in school. We wanted to explore the nature of human sensitivity to nonsymbolic fractions, to know if differences in this sensitivity were related to symbolic math skills, and to know if training using nonsymbolic fractions could lead to improvements in learning. We also wanted to know if we could find evidence of these effects using brain imaging.

Our findings have drawn widespread attention to the human ability to intuitively assess the sizes of nonsymbolic fractions in multiple notations. The work on the grant has resulted in nine peer-reviewed journal publications, a tenth currently under-review, a well-known book chapter that explains our theory in depth, and many conference proceedings and presentations. Our work was also profiled in Psychology Today. Some of our key findings include:

1.     The first demonstration that humans are largely accurate when comparing nonsymbolic fractions and symbolic fractions in multiple notations (Matthews & Chesney, 2015)

2.     The first demonstration that the ability to perceive differences in nonsymbolic fraction sizes is related to overall mathematical ability (Matthews, Lewis & Hubbard, 2016)

3.     The first demonstration that perception of nonsymbolic fraction size is rapid and automatic enough to interfere with the ways we judge sizes of symbolic fractions (Matthews & Lewis, 2017;)

4.     Demonstration that comparisons of symbolic fractions reflects a left-to-right organization along a mental number line (Toomarian & Hubbard, 2018)

5.     Demonstration that nonsymbolic fractions are also arranged left-to-right along something akin to a mental number line (Meng, Toomarian & Matthews, 2019)

6.     Demonstration that humans can rapidly assess the sizes of symbolic fractions without calculating decimal values, suggesting that perceptual mechanisms may support the ways adults think about symbolic fraction sizes (Binzak & Hubbard, 2020).

In sum, we have used multiple methods to test a new hypothesis about how fraction abilities develop and explore implications for education, psychology, and neuroscience. We have highlighted a human ?sense of proportion,? a primitive capacity that can serve as a foundation for learning about fractions concepts. As we continue this line of research, we hope to develop new instructional approaches that build on this capacity can help improve the teaching and learning of fractions to schoolchildren.
